comments.commentBody:
Is the problem really the Trump Administration? Would we being going through this if former Secretary Hillary Clinton hadn't turned the department into her own personal fief? She was followed by Former Secretary John Kerr, who with the rest of the department did yeoman service in blocking the courts and the Congress from obtaining info on Candidate Clinton's activities while she was Secretary of State.

A civil servant in a government can certainly be patriotic, as is, I think, almost every State Department employee, but she or he can't operate as a cog in a politically party's machine and expect the next administration from another party to overlook that.

Our foreign policy has always operated outside the scrutiny of the American voter.  It's understandable that the people of a country that doesn't depend on other countries and that is geographically isolated would not be very knowledgeable about distant lands (that get screwed with).  All I'm saying is that our self-perception, as a country, is far more positive than the general perception of America is to the rest of the world.

Donald needs to be told if he is going to deny any involvement with Russia, he should first wipe away the bit of Russian caviar stuck to the corner of his mouth.

Donald isn’t contemptuous of the press, the courts, or the constitution. He’s just fantastically ignorant of their function and content. The contempt is when they don’t give him what he wants. That partially explains his bromance with Vladimir Putin, who has eliminated Russia’s free press, completely controls the government, and has stolen a fortune. Donald must be dripping with envy.

Just as disturbing is the ignorance and continued support of the people who voted for Trump because he was a “successful” businessman. Never mind his inherited wealth, multiple bankruptcies, multiple marriages, and inability to speak in sentences. Ignore his defense of Putin. When told Vladimir was a killer, Donald responded, “There are a lot of killers, are we (the United States) so innocent?” Yikes. That came out of the mouth of the U.S. president. It sounded like it should have come from the president of Russia. With that utterance, Donald became a joke within the state department, and could explain the need to clean house. Not for the safety and security of the U.S., but to spare wounding Donald’s ego.

Electing Donald is embarrassment enough, but we’ll recover from that. What will be harder to overcome is the damage his incompetence may do to the government and the constitution.

And regretably, Trump has plenty of business deals in China too. Remember Kushner's meeting champaign meeting with the Chinese just after the election?

You're in a tough spot when you have to negotiate for your own wealth and the life of your citizens. http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2017/01/china-trump-deals-investment...

Lots of smoke here!

Manafort, Flynn, Kistner, Sessions, etc... have have lied or misled about their Russian contacts and connections. Appointing one Russia skeptic -- Hill -- to a minor position doesn't change anything, but throws up more smoke.

Without trump's tax returns, it's a safe assumption that he's owned by the Russians and Putin pulls the strings.
Just read up on Trump's choice for Commerce Secretary.  That should open your eyes.
Treason and sedition matter.

I am always suspicious of states rights arguments as they often seem to come from big fish in little ponds trying to maintain their local alpha status. Perhaps more so from Gov. Walker, whose bid to move up to the big pond dried up and blew away because few people really paid any attention to him.
With the Governor now refocussing his efforts on his state, he should be aware that Wisconsin receives about $1.70 in federal dollars for every $1 its citizen pay in federal taxes. If he's interested in going it alone, his neighbors in Illinois and Minnesota, who only get back bout $0.60 on each dollar of federal taxes, would be happy to bet back some of their taxes money back.
Individual states do serve as valuable testing grounds for policies and government systems, but experiments in governing can be and are implemented within federal guidelines. Many federal programs are explicitly designed to encourage states to innovate in delivering government services. But experimentation must also involve careful measurement of the results that flow directly from the experiment. Trying to attribute an increase in jobs to Gov Walker's union busting and budget cutting during a broad period of economic improvement is like trying to attribute a child's growth to the distance of Haley's comet from the sun: Yes, they both are increasing, but one has nothing to do with the other.

Like most Republicans, Scott Walker reveals his total disconnect from society and the electorate he is supposed to represent, by instructing fellow Republican lawmakers to stand firm against protests and protesters, instead of listening to them.
That's the entire problem in a nutshell.

Yes, you would think Mr. Walker would be a champion of local control. As a Wisconsinite, I can assure you that isn't the case. Instead, he and his legislative sycophants stripped local government authority to determine prevailing wages, to protect renters from slumlords, to establish family and medical leave laws, to set standards for shoreland protection and farmland preservation. They even prevented municipal clerks from allowing their residents to vote on weekends. He decries unfunded federal mandates while he forces unfunded state mandates upon local governments. And while forcing these mandates upon local governments, he cuts shared revenue to those very same localities.

Scott Walker isn't interested in local control; he's interested in Republican control. He doesn't want to return power to the people, he wants to increase the GOP's power to advance its ideological agenda. He is arguably the most unimaginative politician in the country, chained to his rigid ideological views. This piece is yet another display of his cramped vision which is decimating the people of our state, while he continues to degrade educators, public employees and, above all, working people and the poor.

His resentment politics has made him the most divisive politician in Wisconsin's history. But he could care less. Our state is in his rear view mirror as he serves his corporate masters and focus on (again) running for president--presumably for more than 10 weeks next time.

Scott Walker here provides one more example of the decline of our political and civic discourse.  He's right in only one respect--those who feel the only legitimate and effective way to engage in political and civic discourse is to protest are equally guilty of debasing that discourse.

You missed the point of those town hall meetings, Mr. Walker. It's not "liberals" turning out to protest--it's everyone who stands to be stripped of health care and be left with nothing to stand in its place. It's people who fear death is the alternative to the ACA because for some of them it is. Until you come up with a real, viable replacement beyond "access" for those who can afford it, protests will continue. And should.

What you missed was that the majority of Americans--Democrats, Republicans, independents want some form of real health care, and don't want to gut Medicare and social security. Those protests are big for a reason. It's not a fringe movement, or even a "liberal" movement, and it's not going away. We cannot and should not continue to be the only westernized nation that views health care as a privilege if you can afford it, death as an acceptable side effect of poverty, and views bankruptcy as a result of medical catastrophe as acceptable.
The centerpiece of the republican agenda - and actually the only item on it - is servicing the short-term financial interests of the 0.1%.

Teachers in Madison public schools began calling the state "Wississippi" after cuts to education. A great, formerly progressive state with a stellar high education system is being disassembled year after year by this autocratic charlatan. "Liberals" and those horrible "progressives" are simply "citizens" who are appalled at the dysfunction and malfeasance.

I have no confidence the states can maintain independent democratic based
principles with the enormity of corporate influence. It is not by accident that 25 states are wholly Republican in both state houses and governorship. All too often,legislation takes place at various conservative/corporate sponsored think tanks, outside state capitols. Only 6 states have a commanding Democratic majority. With this regard and at this rate of republican/corporate take over; Mr. Walker, has nothing to worry about --- the citizenry and our environment perilously does.

Governor, my state's rights, ratified on multiple occasions by the taxpayers who live in our beautiful state, happen to be unrestricted access to reproductive health care, the Death with Dignity Act, environmental protections for our rivers and forests, and legal marijuana.  Just so I'm clear - the Republican party will of course extend its State Rights platform to those rights as well, yes? Because how hypocritical if the GOP had one set of rules for the states with rights that fit their party platform and one set of rules that don't...

Well, since the times has deemed this story worthy of allowing comments, unlike most of the stories based on liberal talking points, I feel the need to comment before the times "Censors" the comments section for their sheep! If the liberal agenda is so important, why did the base not bother to vote? Is it because the segmentation of the democratic based is so parsed on each identity that the ones who understand the process the least are not in the campaign but taken for granted? Socialism always fails due to the simple fact that not all the sheep fall in line with the beloved leaders agenda. Democrats have treated the poor and disenfranchised with more contempt than any good GOP candidate ever thought of!! This pandering and grandstanding is now viewed for what it really is and those not black or in the LGBT or transgender communities realize no one on the liberal side of the fence cares for them!

Republicans are total hypocrites on "states rights." They think it's OK to make healthcare a state responsibility. Are they planning to eliminate federal Medicare? They want federal laws and enforcement of marijuana in conflict with states that have legalized it for medical or all purposes. They want a federal crackdown on immigration in conflict with states that offer sanctuary.

I really like the comment regarding taxes and local control. If "local" control is so important to Scott, why stop at the State level? If local control of the States vs the Federal governments is so good and right, why not see local control of the cities and counties versus the State as even better. All those liberals living in the cities can tax and spend all the funds they need to govern how they want, while the rural people will be left to pursue, with their decisions to cut taxes, their cultural and societal ways. I'd love to see how that works out.

I wish I could recommend this more then once.  I've felt this way for a long time.  Let the tax dollars stay in the places they originate in and see how much unpopulated States like not getting any Federal money.

Imagine a Democrat dismissing 100,000 working class protesters as "intimidation" and then boasting about how effectively they ignored them. Walker reveals (for the millionth time) the true position of the Republican party leadership: paternalistic fantasy over data driven pragmatism. He fails to mention how much the salaries and benefits of those working class people have diminished, and along with it, their spending power. We have yet to hear a justification for why those who do essential work for the state should be martyrs to the cause of conservative tax policy. Is the education of our future work force so worthless to conservatives? The irony is that the Republican's flimsy grasp of free market capitalism is going to come back to bite. Application rates at education preparation programs across the nation are down 50% because college students know it's a raw deal: non-competitive wages, poor working conditions, no respect, and now, eroding benefits. Supply and demand applies to human capital as well - if you're paying like the work isn't in-demand, you aren't going to get quality applicants. The scariest thought is that this may be intentional - illiterate voters are the easiest to control.

I'm overwhelmingly saddened by the vitriol that reigns supreme modern day. It seems civil discourse is a lost skill or perhaps one that no longer has a place in the hashtag fueled mob anger that flairs in an instant due to the speed of electronic communication.

I remember a time when politicians walked freely amount the electorate. Many "candidate coffees" were held at my house growing up - my family was quite entrenched in Ohio politics. Debate on issues was welcomed because screaming matches were considered unthinkable. Candidates listened to their constituents' concerns or objections and honestly attempted to sort it all out and do what was best for the whole of their district. Protest signs weren't unheard of, but no one shouted down a speaker.

It seems today the only opinion that matters is the individual's. There is little thought to consequences for the whole of society. If I disagree with an opinion, I will jump on social media, whip up a like-minded group and go shout down anyone's opposing opinion. My needs MUST be served. Anyone who doesn't see is - fill in the blank with whatever derogatory descriptor is currently trending.

Notice I have not taken a side here - *every* side has it's intolerant mobs who devolve into this behavior, generously covered by an accommodating media which reinforces the screaming. If America is going down in flames, it's because our population blames "them" while remaining blind to their own role in this mess.

Yes, dismiss the protesters and their complaints. Every time republicans win by a squeaker, they govern as though they had a massive mandate to dismantle decades of bipartisan progress.

They continue to cheat with gerrymandering and voter suppression to win majorities with a minority of the vote.

And nowhere is this sub rosa pattern more apparent than Wisconsin, where Koch Brothers' money floated Paul Ryan, Walker, and Reince Priebus.

A fair election is the foundation of democracy. Now, the Republicans are working with the Russians to shape and frustrate the will of the people.

The Republican party is as dangerous to life on this planet as any other fascist or unhinged organization that has come before it. The Republicans collude with the enemies of the USA for political benefit and to maintain their grip on power.

Now Scott Walker, a patsy for the Koch brothers, is attacking one of the fundamental civil rights guaranteed by the founding fathers of the nation.

He should be voted out and prosecuted as the criminal he is.

Scott Walker,'s op ed shades the truth and argues from a false premise. Governor Walker did not campaign on the issues that became his signature piece of legislation, Act 10, which increased the share of health insurance and retirement benefit contributions to be made by teachers, while at the same time stripping them of their collect bargaining rights concerning these issues, causing their take home pay to decrease by over 10%. Not surprisingly, many experienced teacher left early. Police and public safety unions, which had supported Walker, were not affected in the same ways, however. Wisconsin may have balanced its budget, but it has done so by neglecting its public schools, infrastructure, state university system and state parks.

While not even "liberals" condone death threats, the massive protests in Madison, Wisconsin were not the result of liberal opposition to "big government," but to the complete surprise of Act 10's taking away teachers’ collective bargaining rights on economic issues. This sort of "bait and switch" form of governance is the norm for Governor Walker. In his campaign for re-election, when asked about so-called "right to work" laws, he told voters it was not a high priority for him. As soon as he was re-elected, the Republican majority in the Wisconsin legislature sent him just such a bill, which he promptly signed, making Wisconsin a, "right to work," state.
